Example¶

Create a PCM¶

A Profile Classification Model can be created independently of any dataset using the pyxpcm.pcm class constructor:

In [1]: from pyxpcm import pcm

In [2]: m = pcm(K=8, feature_axis=np.arange(-500,0,2), feature_name='temperature')

In [3]: m
Out[3]: 
<pcm 'gmm' (K: 8, Z: 250)>
Number of class: 8
Feature name: 'temperature'
Feature axis: [-500.0, ..., -2.0]
Trained: False
Feature axis Interpolation: False
	 Interpoler: <type 'instance'>
Sample Scaling: 'normal'
	 Scaler: <class 'sklearn.preprocessing.data.StandardScaler'>
Dimensionality Reduction: True
	 Reducer: <class 'sklearn.decomposition.pca.PCA'>
Classification: 'gmm'
	 Classifier: <class 'sklearn.mixture.gaussian_mixture.GaussianMixture'>

The PCM class constructor takes at least 3 arguments:

  • K: the number of class (integer) in the classification model,
  • feature_axis: the vertical axis (numpy array) that the PCM will work with (to train the classifier or to classify new data),
  • feature_name: the name (string) to be used when searching for the feature variable in an xarray.Dataset.

In the above instantiation, we created a PCM with 8 classes that will work with temperature on a vertical axis with a 2m resolution from -500m to the surface. By default, the pyxpcm.pcm class instance is set to use normalisation, dimensionality reduction with Principal Component Analsysis and a Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) as a classifier.

Load a dummy dataset¶

To get you started, you can load a dummy sample dataset of Argo profiles interpolated on standard depth levels:

In [4]: from pyxpcm import datasets as pcmdata

In [5]: ds = pcmdata.load_argo()

In [6]: ds
Out[6]: 
<xarray.Dataset>
Dimensions:    (DEPTH: 21, N_PROF: 100)
Coordinates:
  * DEPTH      (DEPTH) float32 0.0 -5.0 -10.0 -15.0 -20.0 -25.0 -30.0 -35.0 ...
Dimensions without coordinates: N_PROF
Data variables:
    LATITUDE   (N_PROF) float32 dask.array<shape=(100,), chunksize=(100,)>
    LONGITUDE  (N_PROF) float32 dask.array<shape=(100,), chunksize=(100,)>
    TIME       (N_PROF) datetime64[ns] dask.array<shape=(100,), chunksize=(100,)>
    DBINDEX    (N_PROF) float64 dask.array<shape=(100,), chunksize=(100,)>
    TEMP       (N_PROF, DEPTH) float32 dask.array<shape=(100, 21), chunksize=(100, 21)>
    PSAL       (N_PROF, DEPTH) float32 dask.array<shape=(100, 21), chunksize=(100, 21)>
    SIG0       (N_PROF, DEPTH) float32 dask.array<shape=(100, 21), chunksize=(100, 21)>
    BRV2       (N_PROF, DEPTH) float32 dask.array<shape=(100, 21), chunksize=(100, 21)>

This is an xarray.Dataset with 100 profiles with 21 depth levels. Each profile has physical variables such as temperature (TEMP), salinity (PSAL), potentiel density (SIG0) and stratification (BRV2), along with geolocalisation information: latitude (LATITUDE), longitude (LONGITUDE) and time (TIME).

To check out for a single profile, you can simply use the xarray plot method:

In [7]: ds['TEMP'].isel(N_PROF=0).plot()
Out[7]: [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x11bb22210>]

Fit the PCM¶

Now that we have a collection of profiles and a PCM, we can simply fit the classifier:

In [8]: m.fit(ds, feature={'temperature': 'TEMP'})
Out[8]: 
<pcm 'gmm' (K: 8, Z: 250)>
Number of class: 8
Feature name: 'temperature'
Feature axis: [-500.0, ..., -2.0]
Trained: True
Feature axis Interpolation: True
	 Interpoler: <type 'instance'>
Sample Scaling: 'normal'
	 Scaler: <class 'sklearn.preprocessing.data.StandardScaler'>
Dimensionality Reduction: True
	 Reducer: <class 'sklearn.decomposition.pca.PCA'>
Classification: 'gmm'
	 Classifier: <class 'sklearn.mixture.gaussian_mixture.GaussianMixture'>
	 log likelihood: -7.375201

where the pyxpcm.pcm.fit() method requires:

  • a xarray.Dataset, here ds
  • and a feature dictionnary-like argument with the feature_name argument used to instantiate the PCM as a key and with value, the xarray.DataArray name holding this feature in the provided xarray.Dataset.

In the above example we indicate to the PCM instance m that the feature named temperature is to be found in ds['TEMP'].

By default the PCM uses a Gaussian Mixture Model as a classifier. It is computed using the scikit-learn sklearn.mixture.GaussianMixture.

Classification and Prediction¶

Once the PCM is trained, i.e. fitted with a training dataset, we can predict classes that profiles from a xarray.Dataset belongs to. We can simply use the dummy dataset here:

In [9]: LABELS = m.predict(ds, feature={'temperature': 'TEMP'})

In [10]: LABELS
Out[10]: 
<xarray.DataArray 'PCM_LABELS' (N_PROF: 100)>
array([5, 5, 2, 0, 0, 5, 7, 7, 4, 0, 2, 0, 1, 6, 2, 6, 1, 1, 1, 0, 4, 4, 2, 7,
       5, 1, 4, 6, 5, 0, 4, 1, 1, 2, 7, 2, 2, 1, 0, 2, 0, 0, 0, 5, 3, 3, 3, 3,
       0, 7, 7, 7, 5, 6, 6, 0, 7, 5, 5, 5, 6, 6, 5, 1, 2, 6, 6, 1, 4, 2, 0, 0,
       0, 4, 5, 6, 5, 1, 6, 6, 4, 4, 0, 2, 2, 6, 2, 2, 6, 5, 4, 0, 2, 2, 2, 4,
       4, 2, 4, 4])
Dimensions without coordinates: N_PROF
Attributes:
    long_name:  PCM labels
    units:      []
    valid_min:  0
    valid_max:  8
    llh:        -7.375201397879603
